metadata.title: Microstructure and mechanical properties of Al- nano/micro SiC composites produced by stir casting technique

sections.text:
1
In this research, composites of A356- nano SiC (0.5 and 1.5 wt.%) and A356-5 wt.% of micro SiC were produced by stir casting technique. After applying T6 heat treatment on a part of cast ingots, all samples were studied by optical and SEM microscopy and mechanical testing techniques. It was found that adding SiC particles decreases dendrite lengths because the particles act as the preferential nucleation sites for the solidification of matrix. The best modifying effect was observed in the composite containing micro SiC particles. The T6 heat treatment on A356 resulted in the dissociation and globularization of Si platelikes and formation of complex AlMg SiFe intermetallics and nano-sized Mg2Si particles. The mechanical strength of A356 increased considerably by combining T6 heat treatment and adding micro/nano SiC particles. The highest strength was obtained in the composite containing 1.5 wt.% nano SiC. The SEM observations showed that fracture in cast A356 occurs along the dendrite boundaries. However, the T6 treated alloy showed a combined interdendritic and cleavage fracture. The same combined mode of fracture was observed for the alloy with 0.5 wt. % nano SiC. The brittle fracture in the composites was attributed to the existence of SiC and/or intermetallic compounds in the matrix. The fracture mode for other composites was fully cleavage.
Keywords: Stir Casting; Compocasting; Heat treatment; Nanocomposite; Strength; Tensile test.

sections.heading: 1- Introduction
sections.text:
Nowadays, metal matrix composites (MMCs) are widely used for different industrial applications [1, 2]. They are suitable materials which combine the advantages of metals and ceramics. Ceramic materials like Al2O3, SiC, TiO2 and clay are often added to the
2
metallic matrices to provide unique mechanical properties. Such MMCs often inherit ductility and fracture toughness from the metallic matrix and creep resistance and high strength from the ceramic additives [3]. Among the metals, the light alloys of Al, Ti and Mg are desirable to produce MMCs. This is because of the great tendency for light vehicles and structures in different industries. Moreover, the development of MMCs has resolved the lack of enough strength in light alloys. Having low density, good mechanical properties, desirable corrosion resistance and low cost, Al alloys have been the best choice for the manufacture of MMCs in automotive, military and aerospace industries [4, 5]. Al-Si and Al-Cu alloys have been the most common matrices for the production of MMCs by different techniques [6]. Having good castability, the high-Si Al alloys such as A356 (nominally Al-7Si-0.3Mg) have been extensively used for the production of MMCs by compocasting [7-10]. The improved mechanical properties of MMCs arise from the interactions between micro or nano ceramic reinforcing particles with the dislocations in the matrix [7, 11]. Recently, nanoparticles have been substituted for the micro particles in the production of MMCs. It has been approved that nanoparticles, in case of good distribution, show larger strengthening effect due to their more interactions with the dislocations by the Orowan mechanism and contribution to the matrix grain refinement [12-14]. However, the investigations have shown that the fabrication of nano MMCs (NMMCs) by the stir casting technique is challenging. This is because the surface tension increases with decreasing the particle size, leading to less wetability of nanoparticles with the molten metal. Therefore, it is hard to achieve a uniform distribution of nanoparticles in a NMMC [15, 16]. On the other hand, weak wetability leads to incomplete load transfer between the constituents
3
and degrading the mechanical properties of NMMC. Some remedies such as preheating particles, adding Mg or Li to the molten Al, covering or cleaning the particles before use have been found helpful to improve wetability and therefore better distribution of nanoparticles [17]. Different techniques have been so far used for manufacturing MMCs. These techniques are
generally classified into three major groups of (1) liquid-solid processes, (2) solid processes
and (3) deposition techniques. The stir casting and infiltration techniques are located in
the first group [18]. In these techniques solid particles are added to the molten matrix to
attain a desirable distribution. Among these methods, compocasting is simpler and can be
used for a wide variety of industrial parts. While the infilteration techniques needs more
sophisticated machines and produce only small parts [19]. In the solid techniques
category, diffusion bonding methods [20] and powder metallurgy [21] are the most
familiar techniques. Given their promising horizons, both these methods are hardly
industrialized and are so expensive for large-scale productions. In the third group, we can
consider the methods which are adopted for the production of composite coatings such as
spray forming [22], electroplating [23], spray deposition and chemical vapor deposition
[24]. It is clear that amongst the mentioned techniques, compocasting is the handiest
method with the ability to economically produce near-net shape or semi-finished
products. In the original compocasting technique, known as the Vertex method [19], the
additive was directly applied in the melt and there was no coverall or gas purging to
avoid gas absorption into the melt. In the improved techniques some precautions are
followed to acquire a clean MMC.
4
Despite the recent investigations on the production, development and properties of
composites, the topic still needs more investigations, especially in the microstructural and mechanical aspects of micro and nano MMCs. Hence, in current investigation two types of micro and nano MMCs with A356 matrix and different amounts of SiC particles were produced by an improved compocasting technique. The materials were then investigated and compared from the microstructural and mechanical points of view. SEM and optical microscopy observations as well as tensile and compression tests were adopted to characterize the microstructural features and mechanical properties of MMCs in cast and heat treated conditions.

sections.heading: 2- Experimental procedures
sections.text:
2-1- starting materials In this study, A356 aluminum alloy with chemical composition given in Table 1 was adopted
as the metallic matrix. Nano and micro-sized SiC powders with the average particle sizes of 50 nm and 5 micron were used as the strengthener phase. Fig. 1 shows the SEM and TEM images of the SiC powders.
2-2- Compocasting and heat treatment
The ingot of alloy A356 was melted in a graphite crucible by heating up to 800 °C in a
resistant furnace. The surface of molten metal was covered by a suitable coverall material to minimize gas absorption. In order to increase the wetability of particles with the molten metal 1 wt. % Mg was added to the molten metal. It has been approved that Mg reduces the surface tension of Al melt and therefore improves wettability of SiC [25]. However, if the amount of Mg
5
exceeds 1 wt. % increases the viscosity of melt and endangers well distribution of particles [26]. Melt degassing was carried out by using hexachloroethane tablets and then surface slag was
removed. In parallel to the melt preparation, the SiC powders were preheated at 800 °C for 1
hour to eliminate any surface moisture or contamination. The preheating process also would improve wetability by forming oxide layer on the particles surface. The preheated SiC powders were then added to the molten A356 and a mechanical stirrer agitated the melt at 600 RPM for 7 minutes. During stirring, nitrogen was purged on the melt surface to minimize oxidation. Afterwards, the composite was cast into a preheated cylindrical die. The same process was used to produce NMMCs with 0.5 and 1.5 wt. % of nano SiC and a micro MMC with 5 wt. % of micro SiC.
In order to study the influence of heat treatment on the microstructure and mechanical
properties of the A356-SiC composites, T6 heat treatment was applied on the samples. In the
first stages of T6 the samples were heated up to 540 °C and held for 6 hours followed by
quenching in water to the ambient temperature. In the second stage, the artificial aging treatment
was carried out by reheating the samples at 190°C for 4 hours and then air cooling.
2-3- Characterization All the samples (cast or heat treated) were prepared by the standard metallographic techniques
and etched in the Keller’s regent (3 ml HCl, 2 ml HF, 5 ml HNO3, 190 ml H2O). Optical and FEG scanning-electron microscopes were used to study the microstructures.
Tensile and compression tests were adopted to evaluate the mechanical properties of the
samples. Tensile testing was carried out according to the ASTM B557 by a SANTAM STM-150 universal machine. After the tensile tests, the fracture surfaces were studied by using scanning
electron microscope. The uniaxial compression tests were performed according to the ASTM E9 on the cylindrical samples with 15 millimeter in height and 10 mm in diameter and the loadstroke data were converted to the stress-strain curves. Fig. 2 shows the cylindrical and dog bone type samples used for compression and tensile tests, respectively.

sections.heading: 3- Results and Discussion
sections.text:
7
particles and their less wetability with molten metals [15, 16]. Similar results have been reported by Akbari et al. [27] in their work on A356-TiB2 micro/nano composite.

sections.heading: 3-2- Microstructures after T6 heat treatment
sections.text:
Fig. 4 shows the SEM images of pure A356 before and after T6 heat treatment (solutionized at 540 °C for 6 hours + quench in water + artificial aging at 190°C for 4 hours+air cooling) with
two magnifications. Before T6, the microstructure is characterized by island-like a-Al phase
surrounded by the layer-type eutectic of Al-Si. The plate-like Si particles are clearly observed within the eutectic phase in Fig. 4(a). During the solutionizing treatment the dendritic structure
of a-Al is disintegrated and turns into a common granular structure. The Al phase within the
layer-type eutectic of Al-Si is mostly merged into the pre-eutectic a and therefore discrete Si
plate-likes remains within the a matrix. This type of microstructure is clearly observed in the
SEM image presented in Fig. 4(b). In this step, the Si plate-likes pin the a grain boundaries and
limit their further growth. As observed, the microstructure in Fig. 4(b) represents the decoration
of a grain boundaries by the Si particles. In parallel to the evolutions in a phase, the tendency
for decreasing the surface tension energy of a/Si interface leads to the partial or complete
splitting and globularization of the Si plate-likes. As arrowed in Fig. 4(c), Si plate-likes have undergone local narrowing or necking during the early stage of disintegration and globularization. The second step in T6 heat treatment, which is the natural or artificial aging of the solution treated alloy, is often carried out to strengthen the material by the precipitation of some new intermetallic phases. Fig. 5(a) shows that three different phases can be distinguished in the T6 treated microstructure. The EDS technique was used to characterize the particles denoted
by B, C and D in Fig. 5(a). The EDS spectrums exhibited in Figs. 5(b) indicate that the globular grey precipitates denoted by B in Fig. 5(a) are Si particles. According to Fig. 5(c), the rod-like light phase, denoted by C, is an intermetallic composed of Al, Si, Mg and Fe which seems to form during the aging treatment. The previous investigations in the field have reported the formation of different compounds such as FeAl3, Fe2Si2Al9 [28], Al8Mg3FeSi6 [29] and Mg2Si [30], depending on the chemical composition. The EDS spectrum of Fig. 5(d) shows that the dark particles denoted by D in Fig. 5(a) are Al and Si oxides formed during the stir-casting technique.
9
get well-dispersed SiC particles in the MMCs. The unique distribution of such additives is a prerequisite for modifying the cast microstructure as well as improving the mechanical properties through interacting with the matrix dislocations. The influence of micro/nano SiC particles on the mechanical properties of the produced MMCs is addressed in the next section. It is also worthy to note that the magnified FESEM image in Fig. 7(c) and the EDS spectrum in Fig. 7(d) confirm the formation of nano-sized Mg2Si particles during aging which play a great role in strengthening of the alloys [31].
3-3- Mechanical properties Tensile and compression tests were used to evaluate the influence of adding SiC micro/nano particles to A356. Fig. 8 shows the tensile and compression stress-strain curves for the pure A356 and micro/nano MMCs. As expected, adding SiC particles has remarkably increased strength of MMCs in expense of the ductility. Fig. 9 summarizes the tensile and compression strengths of the studied samples. It is observed that the MMC containing 1.5 wt. % of nano SiC has the highest strength both in tensile and compression modes. The interaction of uniquely distributed micro/nano SiC particles with the matrix dislocations is the major source of strength in the MMCs. As it is observed in Fig. 7, the nano-sized SiC have been better distributed in the matrix than the micro-sized one. This helps the particles to more effectively hinder the easy movement of the matrix dislocations and consequently leads to higher strength. On the other hand, the brittle nature of SiC is the major reason for the lower ductility of the MMCs with respect to pure A356. It has been reported that the initial cracks are
formed in the brittle particles and then propagates into the matrix, leading to the final fracture [32]. However, the contribution of intermetallic compounds such as Mg2Si (Figs. 5 and 7), formed during T6 treatment in improving strength and degrading ductility of MMCs should not be ignored. It is observed that the MMC containing 1.5 wt. % nano SiC has the highest strength in both tensile and compression tests. The formation of nano-sized Mg2Si particles were proved in 1.5 wt. % MMC in Figs. 7© and 7(d). The strength of micro/nano MMCs depends on a series of parameters such as size, weight fraction and particles spacing. During plastic deformation of MMCs, the matrix dislocations need to pass through the strengthening particles by the Orowan mechanism. In this case, the driving stress increases exponentially with the decrease in particles spacing. Therefore, there is a direct relationship between strength and the volume fraction of particles or their distance. However, for a given volume fraction, the driving stress decreases with increase in particles average size. In Fig.7 it was shown that too many nano-sized Mg2Si particles has formed during the aging stage of T6 treatment. The results indicate that the combined effects of Mg2Si and nano-sized SiC particles are the major source of the highest strength obtained in MMC containing 1.5 wt. % of nano SiC.
12

sections.heading: 4- Conclusions
sections.text:
The composites of A356 and 0.5 and 1.5 wt.% of nano SiC and 5 wt.% of micro Sic were produced by the stir casting technique. The alloys were then studied by optical and SEM microscopy and mechanical testing techniques. The major results of this investigation can be summarized as follows:
1. The dendrite lengths decreased by adding SiC particles. The micro SiC
particles showed the best modifying effect on dendrites. It was found that the SiC particles accelerate the nucleation rate of dendrites by acting as the preferential nucleation sites in the melt. 2. T6 heat treatment could result in the dissociation of dendrites and
globularization of Si platelikes. Some new complex intermetallics of Al, Mg, Si and Fe and nano-sized Mg2Si particles were also distinguished in the T6 treated microstructure. 3. The mechanical strength of A356 considerably increased by a combination of
T6 heat treatment and adding micro/nano SiC particles. The increase in strength was in expense of ductility. 4. The highest tensile and compression strengths was found in the composite
containing 1.5 wt.% nano SiC. The highest strength was attributed to the optimized combination of particles size, particle spacing and volume fraction. 5. The SEM observations showed the interdendritic fracture for the cast A356.
However, the alloy with T6 treatment condition showed a dual interdendriticcleavage fracture surface. The same dual fracture surface was observed for
13
the composite of A356 with 0.5 wt. % nano SiC. The brittle fracture in these cases was attributed to the existence of SiC and/or intermetallic compounds in the matrix. The fracture mode for other composites with 1.5 wt.% nano SiC and 5 w.% micro SiC was fully cleavage.

metadata.abstractText: In this research, composites of A356nano SiC (0.5 and 1.5 wt.%) and A356-5 wt.% of micro SiC were produced by stir casting technique. After applying T6 heat treatment on a part of cast ingots, all samples were studied by optical and SEM microscopy and mechanical testing techniques. It was found that adding SiC particles decreases dendrite lengths because the particles act as the preferential nucleation sites for the solidification of matrix. The best modifying effect was observed in the composite containing micro SiC particles. The T6 heat treatment on A356 resulted in the dissociation and globularization of Si platelikes and formation of complex AlMg SiFe intermetallics and nano-sized Mg2Si particles. The mechanical strength of A356 increased considerably by combining T6 heat treatment and adding micro/nano SiC particles. The highest strength was obtained in the composite containing 1.5 wt.% nano SiC. The SEM observations showed that fracture in cast A356 occurs along the dendrite boundaries. However, the T6 treated alloy showed a combined interdendritic and cleavage fracture. The same combined mode of fracture was observed for the alloy with 0.5 wt. % nano SiC. The brittle fracture in the composites was attributed to the existence of SiC and/or intermetallic compounds in the matrix. The fracture mode for other composites was fully cleavage.
